awd_titl_txt: STEM-R: Modeling STEM Retention and Departure across Physics, Mathematics, and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers at West Virginia University will develop a new theoretical framework for STEM departure that will detail the reasons why students leave STEM majors. The research extends Tinto's university departure model to include the career exploration process where a student leaves STEM but remains in college. The framework will be developed and tested by extensive measurement of demographic, social, academic, affective (self-efficacy, self-esteem, belonging), career exploration/aspirations and psychological variables at four longitudinal points in physics and mathematics introductory class sequences required for many STEM majors. The longitudinal measurement monitors evolution of a student's STEM career commitment and vocational identity, and determines factors that influence a decision to begin the process of STEM departure or lead to a well-investigated resolution to pursue a STEM career. The research will explore crucial questions influencing university STEM departure, including to what extent departure is preventable by modifying advising protocols, to what extent performance in these gate-keeper classes and its effect on self-efficacy influence the decision to change major, what psychological/social factors mark students beginning to explore non-STEM careers, and to what extent belonging influences retention, particularly of underrepresented women and rural students.  The research will contribute to a deeper understanding of this important phenomenon. It also will inform the national discussion of STEM retention by producing a theoretical framework of STEM departure validated across a large, economically diverse pool of students. 

The research design will implement a multi-stage analysis and measurement with the goal of modeling the process of STEM departure and quantifying the reasons for and markers of the departure process. Researchers will investigate in depth: (1) what modifications are needed in theoretical frameworks for college departure to explain intra-university departure from STEM disciplines, (2) the minimum information required to predict STEM departure and where STEM departure originates, (3) what fraction of STEM departure could be prevented by interventions, (4) how STEM departure markers differ for underserved populations, and (5) how to identify subpopulations of students where interventions will be most effective. Researchers will use institutional class-taking and outcome data to build a set of "survival" probabilities for individual classes and class-taking sequences. Linear regression analysis then be used to analyze how these probabilities are affected by (1) the student's intrinsic characteristics (ability measured by ACT/SAT, race and ethnicity, socioeconomic status, first generation status, and personality profile), (2) the student's academic preparation (high school GPA and high school course-taking patterns), (3) the student's academic performance in his or her current class (measured by attendance patterns and assignment grades), (4) the students current social connectedness to both family and university structures and communities, and (5) the student's current affective state, his or her self-efficacy, sense of belonging, self-esteem, and STEM identity. Latent growth modeling will track changes in these factors over time. In parallel, the student's vocational identity status, his or her state of career exploration and career decision making, will be monitored. Using the four-point longitudinal measurement, transitions in the student's vocational identity state (particularly changes that indicate a renewed career exportation process and therefore the threat of STEM departure) will be correlated with previous changes in survival probabilities and with changes in the student's affective, academic, or social state. Signatures to inform advisers of at risk students and general changes to advising protocols will be developed. Campus social/academic structures that promote retention will be identified. At all levels, differential results for underrepresented students will be investigated with the goal of designing interventions that target these populations.

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in three areas: STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation, and workforce development.

por.por_cntn:
The STEM-R project featured a partnership of education researchers in the Mathematics and Physics Departments at West Virginia University (WVU) with the goal of better understanding the retention of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) majors. An extensive longitudinal dataset was collected from 2015 to present which features three levels of data: institutional data, in-class data, and non-cognitive data collected with a set of survey instruments developed for the project.

Intellectual Merit: Analysis of institutional data allowed advances in the understanding of student retention and the complexities of student trajectories through college. Multiple methods aided in the visualization and understanding of retention including Sankey plots, hazard analysis, and network analysis which were refined and adapted for the project. Figure 1 presents a Sankey plot showing how engineering students progress through their college career. The plot shows that in general students leaving engineering leave STEM altogether. The project introduced the application of hazard analysis to STEM retention. Figure 2 shows the hazard function for leaving college for engineering majors. The hazard is the probability the student leaves college by next semester. The analysis identifies the spring freshman semester as the point of highest risk. The plot shows rural/first-generation hazard is qualitatively different than that of non-rural non-first-generation students with substantial hazards in the spring sophomore semester and that first-generation students continue to have substantial risk of leaving college each spring semester throughout college. Machine learning techniques were applied to understand the factors that went into these hazards. Partnership with the First2 INCLUDES Alliance led the project to pay special attendion to rural-first generation students.

The project collected a substantial set of non-cognitive variables including self-efficacy, belonging, STEM identity, personality, campus connections, and career intentions. The relations of these variable are extremely complicated as shown in Figure 3. Models using these variables to understand career intentions are still being developed.

The project also brought machine learning techniques to bear on the problem of STEM retention and of understanding the factors that go into STEM course success (a key part of STEM retention). Figure 4 shows a decision tree, a common machine learning technique, applied to student outcomes in introductory physics. Grey nodes represent groups of students where most students fail (earn a D, F, or withdraw) and orange nodes represents groups of students where most students succeed (earn an A, B, or C). Each layer of the tree splits students by some decision shown under the node. Figure 4 shows that investing effort in the homework is the most important feature in predicting student success in physics.

Along with these broad themes, the project produced and continues to produce many secondary outcomes: the development of network analytics techniques to understand conceptual understanding, development of path models to understand gender differences in self-efficacy, mediational analysis of academic achievement differences for women, underrepresented students, and first-generation students, as well as improved understanding of what some of the most broadly used physics conceptual instruments actually measure.

Broader Impacts: The project has greatly improved the understanding of retention of STEM students at WVU and with partnership with the First2 INCLUDES Alliance, the retention of rural and first-generation STEM students across the state of West Virginia. The project’s outcomes have been broadly disseminated leading to ongoing collaborations with groups examining similar issues across the country. The dataset is still being collected and analyzed (and will continue to be analyzed for years to come) and should allow the refinement of advising protocols improving the retention of STEM students and the continued development of STEM retention models.

Summary: The STEM-R project has been transformative, collecting a data that will inform the modeling of STEM retention, particularly of rural and first-generation students, for years to come. The project also developed or adapted many quantitative methods to investigate STEM retention and student success. The project led to ongoing partnerships to help all West Virginia STEM students and STEM students across the country.

 


Last Modified: 09/14/2021
Modified by: John C Stewart

Images (1 of )
  • Sankey (flow) plot showing how engineering students at WVU change majors, graduate, or leave college. The horizontal axes represent semesters (summer semesters are not show); therefore, semester 1 is the fall freshman semester.
    John Stewart
    Creative Commons
    John C Stewart
    Figure 1 - Sankey Plot of Engineering Students
  • Hazard plot showing engineering students rate of leaving college by semester. The horizontal axes represent semesters (summer semesters are not show); therefore, semester 1 is the fall freshman semester.
    John Stewart
    Creative Commons
    John C Stewart
    Figure - Hazard Plot for Engineering Students
  • Correlation plot showing the relation of non-cognitive variables such as self-efficacy, identity, belonging, and STEM career intentions. Green lines are positive correlations; red lines negative. Thicker lines are strong correlations.
    John Stewart
    Creative Commons
    John C Stewart
    Figure 3 - Correlation Plot of Non-Cognitive Factors
  • Decision Tree showing factors influencing grade outcomes in introductory physics. Grey nodes represent failing outcomes; orange nodes passing outcomes. Each level of the tree is labeled with the decision used to split the data.
    John Stewart
    Creative Commons
    John C Stewart
    Figure 4 - Decision Tree for Introductory Physics Grades
